bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 12, 1949

div1.p: Kean corrects a case of mistaken identity in a photograph Hench had sent to him, and provides details about his assignments in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 12, 1949
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
12 Dec, '49
My Dear Col. Hench
div1.p:
I think you wrote that you
would be back from Europe on
Dec. 17, so it is about time for me
to get off a letter to meet you at
Rochester and welcome you home.
I hope the divertion of the trip has
given you a good rest. If I could
judge from the pictures of you in
the Norse papers that you sent me
I would say that you had renewed
your youth like the eagle. They gave
you a really boyish look. I suppose
they were Norse, or some Skandinavian
language. Certainly out of my repertoire
which is limited to English French and a
a little Spanish. You will find where
you get around to it, which will I am
sure not been until after Christmas
(Mrs Hench and the children will see to
that), the huge package of Spanish War
photographs which came in due time
from Truby. I got them off by express
about a month ago with Cornelia's
valient assistance, and with comments
written on the back of one-that of Gen.
Fitzhugh Lee and his staff. It is about
the only one which I think is worth copy-
ing. Truby found two of those of La Punta
of interest also as he was stationed there
when he first arrived in Cuba. Truby sup-
posed very naturally that I was in the group
of the VII Corps staff and named the officer
on the left end of the line as Kean.
He was a nice looking fellow but as
I wrote Truby he had more stomach
and straighter legs than I. My broken
and shortened left leg dated from 1891.
He was a volunteer Medical Officer whose
name was Fowler I think. He was attach-
ed to the staff as a surgical expert
who knew how to perform appendec-
tory. A rare accomplishment in those
days! I was not at that time on Gen.
Lee's staff but was Chief Surgeon of
the 1st Division with which I came to
Cuba. But Gen Lee had his eye on
me and soon after the taking of that
photograph Col Maus was relieved as
Chief Surgeon and went back to the U. S.
and I took his place and was promoted
to Lt. Col. of Volunteers. My rank in the
regular Army was Captain. I think I

became Ch. Surgeon VII Army Corps on
March 6, 1899 but did not have that
honor long as the Corps was mustered out
and its constituent units sent home.
But Gen. Lee held on to me and I became
as you know his Chief Surgeon of Western
Cuba. When he went home after a year or
more I went to Gen Woods Staff but
always as a Major, first of Volunteers and
then in 1901 in the regular service.
I had a letter from Truby yesterday
about the pictures which I will
inclose. Dont return it.

We missed you at the annual meeting
of the Reed Memorial Assec. Admer
Stitt, who had been ill a long time,
died some days before the meeting and
it looked as if we would not have a
quorum. But Dr. Gilbert Grovener came
in which made 6 and then we took
5

WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
comment on, they came to me from Truby
a couple of weeks ago. I agreed with him
that they were of no special interest or
importance to the Walter Reed and Yellow
Fever Episode, but had a certain historical
interest in connection with the VII Army
Corps. We both tried to identify the mem-
bers of Gen. Fitzhugh's staff in the photo-
graph. Fortunately there was a date
on it tho. torn off in part. It was Jan. 2
which was clearly, I think in late Jan '99
Truby identified as me, the man on the left
who had a certain facial resemblance to me
but his stomach was bigger than mine ever was
and his legs were straight, whereas one of mine was
always crooked since my fracture of the thigh
6
split into the Knee, in 1891. Most of the faces
were familiar to me, but I have not been
able to recall all the names. My memory,
which was never good for names has been
notably weakened by my illness last spring.
I pointed out in a letter to Truby that I was
not at that time a member of Gen. Lee's
Staff. Col. Louis M. Maus, Med. Dept. was
the Chief Surgeon and is there prominently.
He was relieved as Ch. Surgeon and or-
dered to the U.S. a few weeks after that
picture was taken, and I succeeded him
as Chief Surgeon. I came to Cuba as Chief
Surgeon 1st Division VII Corps, under a dear
old man*Brig. Gen. Keiffer of Ohio., who had been a Brig. Gen. US Army
in the Civil War and later was in Congress,
and because speaker of the H.R. I became
Chief Surgeon of the Corps a few weeks
after that photograph was taken.

I have some where a bundle of papers and
photos of the VII Army Corps, but I have
no systemac files and no clerk to help
me, and so have not been able to put
my hand on this bundle. If and when
I find it I will be able to get most, if
not all the names. Most of them were
Volunteer Officers who went home
when the Corps was mustered out and
dropped out of army life. Cornelia was
afraid that some of the pictures would
be misplaced, so she undertook the job
of packing up and sending off the
big bundle of photographs to your ad-
dress in Rochester. We sent it by express
rather than by registered mail, for it
is much more convenient - for express
the man comes on phone call and takes
AC

it and the bill is sent later. Whereas
to mail any thing, one has to tote it
to the Post Office and stand in line,
and deliver it, which for us old
people is quite an undertaking.

I suppose that after you get home
and look over your big pile of
mail, you will begin to wonder what
the two hurricanes which swept over
Western Cuba have done to your little
little house no 1 at Camp Lazear.
I hope it is are still there.
We hope that Mrs Hench enjoyed
her trip to Europe, and on her
return found the Children all
flourishing. With all good wishes
